<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 379, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 408]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 527, 758, 559]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 758, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 69, 124, 85]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 101, 625, 556]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 101, 611, 121]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 497, 596, 517]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 632, 628, 652]]<|/det|>

\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 69, 700, 88]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 116, 99, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 146, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 688, 135]]<|/det|>
Explain how a satellite may be in a circular orbit around a planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 237, 146, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 237, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
The Earth and the Moon may be considered to be uniform spheres that are isolated in space. The Earth has radius \(R\) and mean density \(\rho\). The Moon, mass \(m\), is in a circular orbit about the Earth with radius \(nR\), as illustrated in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 298, 756, 529]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 543, 534, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 643, 593]]<|/det|>
The Moon makes one complete orbit of the Earth in time \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 590, 724, 609]]<|/det|>
Show that the mean density \(\rho\) of the Earth is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 616, 544, 645]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{3\pi n^3}{GT^2}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 861, 920, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 69, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
The radius \(R\) of the Earth is \(6.38 \times 10^{3} \text{km}\) and the distance between the centre of the Earth and the centre of the Moon is \(3.84 \times 10^{5} \text{km}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 100, 702, 119]]<|/det|>
The period \(T\) of the orbit of the Moon about the Earth is 27.3 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 485, 134]]<|/det|>
Use the expression in **(b)** to calculate \(\rho\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 335, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\rho = .................................................... \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3} \text{[3]}\)

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 69, 908, 89]]<|/det|>
A bar magnet of mass \(180\mathrm{g}\) is suspended from the free end of a spring, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 95, 707, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 392, 532, 411]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 693, 441]]<|/det|>
The magnet hangs so that one pole is near the centre of a coil of wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 453, 764, 472]]<|/det|>
The coil is connected in series with a resistor and a switch. The switch is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 484, 918, 518]]<|/det|>
The magnet is displaced vertically and then allowed to oscillate with one pole remaining inside the coil. The other pole remains outside the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 530, 918, 564]]<|/det|>
At time \(t = 0\), the magnet is oscillating freely as it passes through its equilibrium position. At time \(t = 3.0 \text{s}\), the switch in the circuit is closed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 577, 848, 596]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 103]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
An electron having charge \(-q\) and mass \(m\) is accelerated from rest in a vacuum through a potential difference \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 100, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
The electron then enters a region of uniform magnetic field of magnetic flux density \(B\), as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 147, 794, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 336, 532, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 710, 387]]<|/det|>
The direction of the uniform magnetic field is into the plane of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 845, 402]]<|/det|>
The velocity of the electron as it enters the magnetic field is normal to the magnetic field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 399, 695, 418]]<|/det|>
The radius of the circular path of the electron in the magnetic field is \(r.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 431, 144, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 431, 792, 450]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 585, 146, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 920, 619]]<|/det|>
Show that the magnitude \(p\) of the momentum of the electron as it enters the magnetic field is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 630, 562, 653]]<|/det|>
\[p = \sqrt{(2mqV)}.\]
